title: Potential energy - U from force - speed from U

content.question: Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. A system is comprised of two objects, <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> and <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math>, which interact with each other through a conservative force <math alttext="F sub B A, end sub, of x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>F</mi><mtext>BA</mtext></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math> is the position of Object <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> with respect to Object <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math>. The potential energy <math alttext="U sub B A, end sub, of x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>U</mi><mtext>BA</mtext></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> of the two-object system as a function of <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math> is shown in Figure <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. No external forces are exerted on the two-object system. Object <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> has mass <math alttext="m sub A" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></msub></math> and is released from rest at position <math alttext="x equals 3 times x sub 0" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>. Object <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> starts moving, and later passes through position <math alttext="x equals 7 times x sub 0" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>7</mn><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>. (a) i. Derive an expression for the speed of Object <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> at the instant Object <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> is passing through position <math alttext="x equals 7 times x sub 0" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>7</mn><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>. Express your answer in terms of <math alttext="m sub A" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></msub></math>, <math alttext="U sub 0" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>U</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>, <math alttext="x sub 0" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate. Begin your derivation by writing a fundamental physics principle or an equation from the reference booklet.

frqParts.text: Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. A system is comprised of two objects, <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> and <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math>, which interact with each other through a conservative force <math alttext="F sub B A, end sub, of x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>F</mi><mtext>BA</mtext></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math> is the position of Object <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> with respect to Object <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math>. The potential energy <math alttext="U sub B A, end sub, of x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>U</mi><mtext>BA</mtext></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> of the two-object system as a function of <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math> is shown in Figure <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math>. No external forces are exerted on the two-object system. Object <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> has mass <math alttext="m sub A" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></msub></math> and is released from rest at position <math alttext="x equals 3 times x sub 0" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>3</mn><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>. Object <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> starts moving, and later passes through position <math alttext="x equals 7 times x sub 0" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>7</mn><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>. (a) i. Derive an expression for the speed of Object <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> at the instant Object <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> is passing through position <math alttext="x equals 7 times x sub 0" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>7</mn><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>. Express your answer in terms of <math alttext="m sub A" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></msub></math>, <math alttext="U sub 0" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>U</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>, <math alttext="x sub 0" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>, and physical constants, as appropriate. Begin your derivation by writing a fundamental physics principle or an equation from the reference booklet.

ii. On the grid shown in Figure <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math>, draw a graph of the force exerted on Object <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> by Object <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math>.

In another scenario, Object <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> is replaced by Object <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math>. Objects <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math> and <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math> interact with each other through a conservative force <math alttext="F sub B C, end sub, of x equals, negative beta times x squared" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mi>F</mi><mtext>BC</mtext></msub><mrow><mo>(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mi>β</mi><msup><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msup></mstyle></math>, where <math alttext="beta equals, three eighths kilogram per second squared meter" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>β</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mn>3</mn><mn>8</mn></mfrac><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mfrac><mtext>kg</mtext><mrow><msup><mtext>s</mtext><mn>2</mn></msup><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mfrac></math>. The potential energy <math alttext="U sub B C of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>U</mi><mtext>BC</mtext></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math> of the Object <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>C</mtext></math>-Object <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math> system is defined to be zero when Object <math alttext="C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">C</mi></math> is at position <math alttext="x equals negative 2 meters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mpadded><mo>-</mo><mn>2</mn></mpadded><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></math>. No external forces are exerted on the two object system.(b) Derive an equation for <math alttext="U sub B C, end sub, of x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>U</mi><mtext>BC</mtext></msub><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>x</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></math>. Express your answer only in terms of <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math>. Begin your derivation by writing a fundamental physics principle or an equation from the reference booklet.

skill.text: 1.C: Create qualitative sketches of graphs that represent features of a model or the behavior of a physical system.
